Expectation1: Listen actively and provide emotional support when needed.
Situation1: Your I04iend calls you in the middle of the night, crying, because they just received some devastating family news.
Expectation2: Provide initial medical care to patients
Situation2: The ambulance driver is responding to a patient with symptoms of a major heart attack
Story:
My phone buzzed violently on the nightstand, jolting me awake. It was Sam, my closest friend, sobbing so hard I could barely make out the words. “It’s Dad… he’s gone. I don’t know what to do.” My heart clenched. I wanted nothing more than to listen, to be the friend Sam needed—someone to hold space for his pain, to offer comfort in the darkness.

But just as I opened my mouth to speak, my radio crackled to life. “Unit 12, we have a Code Red. Possible major heart attack, Maple and 5th. Immediate response required.” My training kicked in, adrenaline surging. Someone’s life depended on me getting there fast, providing care only I could give in those first critical minutes.

Sam’s voice trembled in my ear, desperate for support. The dispatcher’s voice echoed in my other ear, demanding action. I was split in two—torn between the friend who needed me to listen, and the patient who needed me to save their life. My hands shook as I stared at the phone, caught in the impossible space between two worlds, each demanding all of me at once.
